citeinfo.origin: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, James Bodkin of the U.S. Geological Survey, Anchorage, Alaska and Thomas A. Dean of Coastal Resources Associates, Inc., Carlsbad, California.
citeinfo.title: GEM Nearshore Metadata References Metadatabase

descript.abstract: A metadatabase of reference collection which includes studies of a select assemblage of marine taxa, including alga, invertebrates, fishes, birds, and mammals that occupy nearshore habitats of the Gulf of Alaska. Also consists of GIS (Arc View themes) dataset that allow geographic representation of the metadata identifying habitat types, locations of historical data, and types of historical data available from each site, existing human use, and biological hotspots. Data are maintained in digital format (ArcView 3.3, Excel 2002, and Procite) at the Alaska Science Center, USGS in Anchorage, Alaska. The information obtained from the literature review was entered into an Excel database labeled GEM Nearshore Metadata Set (APPENDIX C, CD-ROM). The Nearshore Metadata Set contains a worksheet with the field information. The Excel database is also viewable in ArcView within tables specific to resources. The citations are linked to a ProCite database. The Gulf Ecosystem Monitoring and Research Project final report, which describes the metadatabase and the GIS dataset in detail, can be found at http://www.evostc.state.ak.us/pdf/GEM_final_reports/030687.pdf. [Reference: Bodkin, J. L., and T. Dean. 2003. Alternative Sampling Designs for Nearshore Monitoring (Gulf Ecosystem Monitoring and Research Project G-030687), US Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center, Anchorage, Alaska.]
descript.purpose: Part of the design effort of a nearshore monitoring program for the nearshore habitats of the Gulf of Alaska. To provide an alternative sampling designs that can detect change, over varying scales of space and time, with reasonable certainty.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system. NOAA makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty.

metainfo.metstdn: Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata
